questions.text: A male child presented with easy bruisability leading to detailed investigations which revealed normal PT, prolonged APTT and normal bleeding time. Which of the following cannot be cause of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von willebrand disease

 

The combination of normal prothrombin time (PT), prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), and normal bleeding time indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which includes factors VIII, IX, and XI.

 

  • Factor 8 deficiency (Hemophilia A), Factor 9 deficiency (Hemophilia B), and Factor 11 deficiency (Hemophilia C) all cause a prolonged APTT with normal PT and bleeding time.

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) affects both platelet function and the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, leading to an increased bleeding time and often a prolonged APTT. However, the presence of a normal bleeding time in this patient rules out vWD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor 8 deficiency: This would present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option B. Factor 9 deficiency: This would also present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option C. Factor 11 deficiency: This would similarly present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isolated increased APTT can be caused by clotting factor deficiency of the intrinsic pathway like hemophilia A/B/C. von Willebrand disease is associated with increased bleeding time and increased APTT.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin and reduced reticulocyte count. His WBC and platelet count were normal. BM examination reveals selective reduction in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Red cell aplasia 

 

Explanation:

 

This patient's presentation is classic for red cell aplasia. Think about what's happening here - the patient has anemia (shown by fatigue, pallor, weakness, and low hemoglobin), but interestingly, only the red blood cell line is affected. The white cells and platelets are completely normal.

 

The hallmark of red cell aplasia is that there is a selective reduction in erythroid precursors. The reduced reticulocyte count is also important as it tell us that the bone marrow isn't even trying to compensate for the anemia

 

Red cell aplasia can happen for several reasons - parvovirus B19 infection, certain medications, autoimmune disorders, or sometimes associated with thymomas. 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Aplastic anaemia If this were aplastic anemia, our patient would be having pancytopenia (low counts across all cell types). Our patient's normal WBC and platelets immediately rule this out.
  • Option C: Iron deficiency anemia; in IDA, the body typically responds by pumping out more reticulocytes to try to compensate. Our patient has reduced Reticulocyte count ruling this out. 
  • Option D: Hemolytic anemia would show increased red cell precursors leading to high reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests knowledge of the differential diagnosis of anemia based on bone marrow findings and cellular indices. Specifically, it assesses the ability to recognize the characteristic pattern of red cell aplasia: selective reduction of erythroid precursors with normal myeloid and megakaryocytic lines, accompanied by anemia and low reticulocyte count. The key distinguishing feature is the selective involvement of only the red cell line, differentiating it from other anemias that show different patterns of cell production or destruction.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paracetamol

 

The most common cause of liver failure is paracetamol poisoning.

 

Acetaminophen is the leading cause of drug-induced acute liver failure. The most common prescription drugs causing idiosyncratic injury (that is, drug toxicity unrelated to drug dosage) include antibiotics and, in particular, isoniazid, nonsteroidal analgesics, and anti-seizure.

 

  • Paracetamol poisoning is a medical emergency that requires prompt management to prevent serious liver damage and other complications. The general steps involved in the management of acute paracetamol poisoning:

 

1. Decontamination: If the ingestion of paracetamol occurred within the last 1-2 hours, activated charcoal can be given orally to reduce the absorption of paracetamol.

 

2. Treatment with antidote: N-acetylcysteine (NAC. is the specific antidote for paracetamol poisoning. It is most effective if given within 8 hours of ingestion of the overdose. NAC replenishes the depleted glutathione stores in the liver, which helps to prevent liver damage.

 

3. Monitoring and supportive care: Patients with paracetamol poisoning require close monitoring, particularly for liver and kidney function, electrolytes, blood glucose, and acid-base balance. Treatment with intravenous fluids, glucose and electrolytes may be necessary to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.

 

RUMACK MATTHEW NOMOGRAM is used for monitoring:

 

 

4. Referral for specialist care: In severe cases of paracetamol poisoning, the patient may require specialist care in a hospital setting, including referral to a liver transplant center.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol: Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant cause of liver disease, including cirrhosis, but paracetamol is the leading cause of acute liver failure.

 

Option C. CCl4 (Carbon Tetrachloride): CCl4 is a chemical that can cause liver damage, but it is not a common cause of liver failure compared to paracetamol.

 

Option D. Pesticides: Certain pesticides can cause liver toxicity, but they are not as common a cause of liver failure as paracetamol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracetamol poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure, the mechanism involves free radical injury and so and it is a medical emergency that requires prompt treatment with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and close monitoring to prevent serious complications, including liver failure.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 11th edition, Pg 1635

questions.text: Transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL is referred to as which of the following? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Richter syndrome

 

Explanation: 

 

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). This transformation occurs in approximately 5-10% of CLL/SLL patients and is often heralded by the development of a rapidly enlarging mass within a lymph node or the spleen. Richter syndrome is frequently associated with acquisition of new abnormalities involving TP53 or MYC genes and represents an ominous event, with most patients surviving less than 1 year after transformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Evans syndrome - This is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the simultaneous or sequential occurrence of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). It has no relation to the transformation of CLL/SLL to DLBCL.

 

Option C. Li-Fraumeni syndrome - This is an inherited cancer predisposition syndrome associated with germline mutations in the TP53 tumor suppressor gene. It is characterized by a high risk of developing various cancers but is not related to CLL/SLL transformation.

 

Option D. Kostmann syndrome - This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by severe neutropenia, leading to recurrent infections. It is unrelated to CLL/SLL transformation and represents a disorder of granulocyte production.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Richter syndrome represents the clinically aggressive transformation of CLL/SLL into DLBCL, characterized by rapidly enlarging masses, new genetic abnormalities, and poor prognosis with survival usually less than one year.

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

 

Hirschsprung disease is caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall.

 

Hirschsprung disease, also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon, occurs when the normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum is interrupted or the ganglion cells die prematurely. This results in a distal intestinal segment with neither the Meissner submucosal nor the Auerbach myenteric plexus ("aganglionosis"). Coordinated peristaltic contractions are absent, and functional obstruction occurs, resulting in proximal dilation.

 

The absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel leads to an inability to coordinate peristaltic contractions, resulting in functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation. This can lead to symptoms such as abdominal distension, constipation, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

 

The diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease is made based on a combination of clinical presentation, radiographic findings, and histologic examination of rectal biopsy specimens. Treatment typically involves surgical resection of the aganglionic segment of the bowel, followed by re-anastomosis or creation of a colostomy.

 

Complications of Hirschsprung disease include enterocolitis, fecal impaction, and even sepsis, so early diagnosis and prompt treatment are important to prevent these complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of ganglion cells: While the result of the disease is a bowel segment lacking ganglion cells, the primary cause is the failure of migration of neural crest cells rather than a secondary loss of ganglion cells.

 

Option C. Visceral myopathy: Visceral myopathy involves primary muscle pathology of the bowel, which is not the cause of Hirschsprung disease.

 

Option D. Obstruction by inflammatory stricture: Inflammatory strictures are not related to the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease, which is due to congenital aganglionosis rather than inflammation or stricture formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text: Which of the following Immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SOX11

 

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 2.5% of NHL.

 

The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

 

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours.

 

Immunohistochemistry - Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. Most tumors are also express CD19, CD20, and moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain). It is usually CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Cyclin D1 (CCND1) protein overexpression and/or the t(11;14) (q13;q32) translocation are the pathognomonic hallmarks of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). SOX11 expression serves as a specific biomarker in cases lacking both t (11;14) and cyclin D1 protein but having a gene expression profile suggestive of MCL. SOX11 expression is associated with bad prognosis in mantle cell lymphoma.

 

  • MYD88: Associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia.
  • Annexin V: Generally used in apoptosis studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of NHL: -

questions.text: Based on the patient's history of relapsing, remitting, mildly itchy erythematous plaques on the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain and the displayed nail changes in the image below, what would be your diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

 

The diagnosis in this patient showing nail pitting, oil drop sign, and salmon patches in fingernails is psoriasis.

 

  • The nail changes shown in the image, such as nail pitting and onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed), along with the patient's history of itchy erythematous plaques and joint pain, are characteristic of psoriasis.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Adult-onset Still's disease:

 

This systemic inflammatory condition typically presents with a salmon-pink rash, fever, and arthritis but is not typically associated with the nail changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Pachyonychia congenita:

 

A rare genetic condition affecting the nails, characterized by thickened nails (pachyonychia) as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option D. Lichen planus:

 

This condition can affect the nails, causing thinning and splitting, and it can also lead to lacy white lesions on the mucous membranes (Wickham's striae), but the nail changes in the image are more characteristic of psoriasis, and lichen planus doesn’t commonly cause joint pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When presented with nail pitting, onycholysis, erythematous plaques with scales on common sites such as the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain, consider psoriasis as a likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: Which of the following is the method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucodepleted blood

 

Explanation:

 

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are caused by antibodies in the recipient's plasma reacting with the donor's white blood cells (leukocytes) present in the transfused blood. The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the leukocytes, significantly reduces the risk of FNHTRs by eliminating the trigger for the antibody reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol may help in managing fever if an FNHTR occurs, but it does not prevent the reaction itself.

 

Option B. Intravenous steroids are not typically used for the prevention of FNHTRs. Steroids may be administered in cases of severe transfusion reactions, but they do not specifically target the underlying cause of FNHTRs.

 

Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion is a method used to reduce the risk of allergic reactions due to the presence of plasma proteins, but it does not directly address the issue of FNHTRs caused by leukocyte antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the donor's white blood cells, is the recommended method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions caused by antibody reactions against the transfused leukocytes.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Alcohol and its metabolites, acetaldehyde, have a toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy causes include:

 

Acquisition of causes

 

  • The most frequent causes of myocarditis worldwide are infectious (particularly coxsackievirus B) and non-infectious myocarditis.
  • In India, alcohol is the most frequent culprit.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PCM) and pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) (PPCM)
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy brought on by stress

 

Meth-related:

 

  • Doxycycline (anthracycline)
  • Cyclophosphamide and trastuzumab

 

A lack of nutrition:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency; Keshan disease (selenium); Beriberi (thiamine);
  • Endocrine: acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, hypo- and hyperthyroidism
  • Additional
  • Toxicity of cobalt, Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)

 

Genetic factors (50%):

 

Haemochromatosis; Duchenne muscular dystrophy; Becker's muscular dystrophy; cardiac myocyte titin gene mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericarditis: While alcohol can have widespread effects on the body, it is not directly associated with the development of pericarditis.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: This condition involves the thickening of the heart muscle, primarily due to genetic causes, and is not directly linked to alcohol use.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Generally caused by infections (particularly viral), autoimmune disorders, or toxic exposures, but not specifically by alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

 

Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by abnormal diastolic filling with relatively preserved systolic function. The histology often shows increased myocardial stiffness due to fibrosis, which is evident as diffuse fibrotic deposition within the myocardium. The cardiac muscle appears normal in size or slightly hypertrophic without significant dilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Typically shows dilated heart chambers and significant myocardial thinning with fibrosis, which is not evident in the provided histology image.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Characterized by marked hypertrophy of the myocardium, especially the septum.

 

Option D. Atrial fibrillation: This is primarily an electrical disorder of the heart, typically not diagnosed via myocardial biopsy and does not have a distinctive histopathological appearance related to the rhythm disorder itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

questions.text: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein is necessary for this process.

 

Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.

 

The removal of self-reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. A protein called AIRE (autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some “peripheral tissue-restricted” self-antigens in the thymus and is thus critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy

 

B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells can also undergo apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: Involved in T cell development but not specifically in the central tolerance process.

 

Option B. RB gene: A tumor suppressor gene involved in regulating the cell cycle, not in immune tolerance.

 

Option C. CPK gene: Not relevant to the process of central tolerance or immune regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for central tolerance in the thymus, preventing autoimmunity by ensuring the deletion of self-reactive T cells.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 397-398

questions.text: Match the malignancies with the responsible genes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pleomorphic adenoma: This benign salivary gland tumor is associated with the overexpression of the Plag-1 proto-oncogene. Plag-1 plays a significant role in the tumorigenesis of pleomorphic adenoma, making option d the correct match.
  2. Burkitt's lymphoma: This aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation of the C-myc gene, particularly t(8;14) or t(8;22). This translocation leads to the overexpression of the C-myc oncogene, driving the proliferation of lymphoid cells, making option c the correct match.
  3. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood and is associated with amplification of the N-myc gene. N-myc plays a critical role in the aggressive behavior of neuroblastoma, making option b the correct match.
  4. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, is associated with mutations in the Rb gene. The Rb gene is a tumor suppressor that regulates cell cycle progression, and its inactivation leads to uncontrolled cell division, making option a the correct match.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The cell marked in the image below is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mast cell

 

The marked cell is Mast cell which is stained deep blue with Toluidine blue.

 

 

Mast cells are a part of innate immunity and these cells are responsible for the allergic or hypersensitivity reactions.

 

When an antigen binds to IgE antibodies on the surface of the mast cell, they get activated and degranulation occurs releasing various mediators like Histamine, chymase, tryptase, heparin, Lipid mediators (Leukotriene C4, D4), prostaglandin D2, platelet-activating factor cytokines (TNF, IL 1).

questions.text: Which cytokine is responsible for activating macrophages and converting them into giant cells? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IFN-gamma.

 

Explanation: 

 

IFN-gamma (Interferon gamma) is produced by T-lymphocytes and natural killer cells and is a critical cytokine for macrophage activation. It induces classical activation of macrophages, enhancing their microbicidal activity and promoting granuloma formation, which includes the fusion of macrophages to form multinucleated giant cells like Langhans giant cells. IFN-gamma is particularly important in immune responses against intracellular pathogens, especially mycobacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IL-12 - Though IL-12 is involved in the immune response, it primarily functions to stimulate the development of Th1 cells and the production of IFN-gamma. It plays an indirect role in macrophage activation by promoting IFN-gamma production, but doesn't directly convert macrophages into giant cells.

 

Option B. IL-7 - This interleukin is primarily involved in lymphoid proliferation and development. It stimulates the proliferation of B, T, and NK cell progenitors, but does not directly activate macrophages or contribute to giant cell formation.

 

Option C. IFN-alpha - While IFN-alpha (Interferon alpha) has antiviral activities and is produced by leukocytes, it doesn't play a significant role in macrophage activation or giant cell formation. Its primary function is interfering with viral DNA and RNA synthesis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

IFN-gamma is the key cytokine responsible for classical macrophage activation, which can lead to the formation of giant cells in granulomatous inflammation, particularly in response to persistent intracellular pathogens like mycobacteria.

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

 

Explanation

 

  • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Enterovirus 70:

 

  • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.

 

Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV):

 

  • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.

 

Option D. VZV:

 

  • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MYC gene

 

The given clinical scenario and the classical histopathological finding of starry sky appearance suggest the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and the most likely genetic abnormality is the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Typical cytogenetic abnormalities is t(8;14) and t(8;22) involving MYC gene on chromosome 8, with overexpression of MYC protein having transforming activity.

 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive (very high Ki67) but responds well to intensive chemotherapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RAS: Mutations in the RAS gene are associated with various cancers, including some leukemias and solid tumors, but not specifically with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. BCR-ABL: This genetic abnormality is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. p53: Mutations in the p53 gene are common in many types of cancer but are not the defining feature of Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by the t(8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene, which leads to the overexpression of the MYC protein, driving the aggressive nature of the disease. The starry sky appearance on histopathology is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1123

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presented to the clinic and underwent karyotyping. What is the likely diagnosis in the karyotype shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Turner syndrome

 

The karyotype image shows 45 chromosomes with a single X chromosome and no second sex chromosome, confirming a 45, XO karyotype, which is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome is a condition caused by complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome, leading to the absence of one X chromosome. This genetic abnormality is commonly associated with infertility, short stature, webbed neck, and a variety of other clinical features.

 

Turner syndrome is a common cause of primary amenorrhea due to ovarian dysgenesis (underdeveloped ovaries), which leads to hormonal imbalances that prevent normal menstruation and fertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: Down syndrome, or trisomy 21, is characterized by an extra chromosome 21, resulting in 47 chromosomes. It is associated with intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and other health complications, not infertility related to the absence of an X chromosome.

 

Option C. Klinefelter syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with a 47, XXY karyotype. Patients typically have an extra X chromosome and may present with infertility, gynecomastia, and tall stature. It does not occur in females and does not present as 45, XO.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome, or trisomy 18, is characterized by an extra chromosome 18, leading to 47 chromosomes. It presents with severe developmental delays and congenital abnormalities. It is unrelated to the XO karyotype seen in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, XO karyotype, where there is a complete or partial absence of the second X chromosome, leading to infertility, primary amenorrhea, and other characteristic features.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of a child with cleft lip and palate with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patau syndrome

 

The clinical features described in the question—cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia (small eyes), and umbilical hernia—are characteristic of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). Patau syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 13.

 

Children with Patau syndrome often present with multiple congenital anomalies, including:

 

  • Cleft lip and palate
  • Microphthalmia (small, underdeveloped eyes)
  • Umbilical hernia
  • Polydactyly (extra fingers or toes)
  • Congenital heart defects
  • Rocker-bottom feet

 

These features, especially when occurring together, strongly suggest a diagnosis of Patau syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edward syndrome: Also known as Trisomy 18, it is characterized by features like micrognathia (small jaw), prominent occiput, overlapping fingers, and rocker-bottom feet. While some features overlap with Patau syndrome, the presence of cleft lip and palate along with microphthalmia and umbilical hernia points more towards Patau syndrome.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome affects females and is caused by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome. It is associated with features such as short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis, but not with cleft lip, palate, or microphthalmia.

 

Option D. Prader-Willi syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, obesity, intellectual disability, and hypogonadism, but not by cleft lip and palate or microphthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) presents with multiple congenital anomalies, including cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and umbilical hernia, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with multiple patches of hair loss which was associated with itching and scaling. His 2-year-old sister also had similar complaints. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tinea capitis

 

Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp that commonly affects children. It is characterized by multiple patches of hair loss, which are often associated with itching and scaling.

 

The history of a sibling with similar symptoms strongly suggests an infectious cause, which aligns with the diagnosis of tinea capitis. The condition is caused by dermatophyte fungi, and the transmission occurs via direct contact or shared objects, making it contagious, particularly among children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alopecia areata: This condition leads to sudden, patchy hair loss but is not associated with itching, scaling, or being contagious. It is an autoimmune disorder rather than an infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Seborrheic dermatitis: While this condition can cause scalp scaling, it typically does not lead to well-defined patches of hair loss or the contagious spread noted in this case.

 

Option D. Pediculosis capitis: Also known as head lice, this condition causes intense itching but does not result in patchy hair loss or scaling. The primary symptom is the presence of lice and nits (lice eggs) on the scalp.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea capitis is a contagious fungal infection that presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling, particularly in children, and can spread among family members.

choices.text: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IP to IRE

 

In iron deficiency anaemia, ferritin translation is decreased by binding iron regulatory protein to iron response elements.

 

Dietary iron is carried in the blood by transferrin and enters cells via endocytosis, mediated by the transferrin receptor. Excess iron is stored by binding to ferritin. The levels of transferrin, transferrin receptor (TfR), and ferritin are therefore crucial to cellular iron homeostasis.

 

The iron regulatory proteins (IRPs) are two cytoplasmic RNA-binding proteins that control iron metabolism which bind to iron response elements (IRE) which are mRNA regions consisting of ferritin and transferrin receptor.

 

When the IRPs bind to the 5' untranslated IRE sequence in the ferritin mRNA, ferritin translation is blocked resulting in decreased ferritin.

 

When IPs are bound to the 3' end of the untranslated IRE sequence, there is increase in transferrin receptor per mRNA molecule due to reduced proteolysis of Tf receptor.

 

In iron-deficiency, iron stores (ferritin) is reduced and iron uptake (through transferrin receptor) is increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect because binding of IRP to IRE inhibits ferritin translation.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect. IRP binding to IRE at the 3' untranslated region of transferrin receptor mRNA actually increases the stability and translation of transferrin receptor mRNA, increasing iron uptake.

 

Option D. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect as described above; binding of IRP to IRE increases transferrin receptor 1 translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, ferritin translation is decreased due to the binding of IRP to IRE in the ferritin mRNA, reducing iron storage and making more iron available for use.

questions.text: Methylisothiazolinone (MI) in cosmetics is used as? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preservative

 

Methylisothiazolinone (MIT) is a preservative present in various facial cosmetics, deodorants, sunscreens, and industrial products. The frequency of contact dermatitis resulting from either Methyl-chloro-isothiazolinone/methylisothiazolinone (MCI/MIT or Kathon CG) or MIT has been on the rise.

 

 

Moreover, there have been reported cases of severe airborne and generalized dermatitis caused by exposure to MIT through recently painted walls and even from toilet cleaners.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

It's important to understand that Methylisothiazolinone (MI) is used as a preservative in cosmetics to prevent microbial growth, distinguishing it from surfactants, humectants, and emulsifiers, which have different functional roles in product formulation.

 

Ref:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 128, Page no 128.36

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4689087/

questions.text: A diabetic patient's blood sample was taken in a grey top vacutainer. Which of the following is added for the correct estimate of blood glucose? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium fluoride

 

Explanation:

 

For accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients, the blood sample is collected in a grey top vacutainer containing sodium fluoride. Sodium fluoride acts as a glycolysis inhibitor, preventing the breakdown of glucose by red blood cells. This ensures that the glucose levels in the sample remain stable until the analysis is performed, providing an accurate representation of the patient's blood glucose concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium citrate is used as an anticoagulant and is present in blue top vacutainers, which are typically used for coagulation studies and not for glucose estimation.

 

Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is an anticoagulant used in lavender top vacutainers, which are commonly used for complete blood count (CBC) and other hematological tests, but not for glucose estimation.

 

Option D. Heparin is an anticoagulant found in green top vacutainers, which are used for various biochemical tests, but not specifically for glucose estimation in diabetic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sodium fluoride, present in grey top vacutainers, inhibits glycolysis and prevents the breakdown of glucose, ensuring an accurate measurement of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with violaceous plane topped papules associated with pruritus over wrist and antecubital fossae for 2 months. The lesions have a characteristic shiny surface and are arranged in a linear pattern. What is the first line of treatment in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Topical steroids

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is topical steroids.

 

The patient presents with classic signs of lichen planus, which includes violaceous (purple) plane-topped papules that are intensely pruritic (itchy). These lesions are commonly found on the flexor surfaces such as the wrists and antecubital fossae.

 

Lichen planus is a self-limiting condition that usually resolves spontaneously within about 2 years. However, due to the extreme itching, symptomatic treatment is necessary.

 

Topical steroids are the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus, providing relief from itching and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antifungals: These are not used in the treatment of lichen planus, as it is not a fungal infection.

 

Option B. Oral steroids: While oral steroids can be used in more extensive cases of lichen planus, they are not the first-line treatment for localized lesions.

 

Option D. Phototherapy: This can be used in extensive cases but is not the first-line treatment for localized lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lichen planus, characterized by violaceous, pruritic, plane-topped papules with a shiny surface, is best treated initially with topical steroids when the condition is localized. ​

questions.text: A patient with alkaline urine has the presence of the following type of urinary crystals. What is the likely composition of these crystals?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

The presence of urinary crystals can help diagnose the type of stones a patient may be forming. The type of crystal seen in the urine is highly dependent on the urine pH:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite): These crystals are typically found in alkaline urine and have a characteristic "coffin lid" appearance. They are associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria and are also known as staghorn calculi due to their large, branching structure in the kidneys.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Calcium oxalate: These crystals are typically found in acidic to neutral urine and have an envelope or dumbbell shape. They are the most common type of kidney stones.

 

Option B. Uric acid: These crystals are found in acidic urine and often have a rosette or irregular shape.

 

Option C. Cystine: These crystals appear in acidic urine and have a hexagonal shape, associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate crystals, which appear as "coffin lid" shapes, are typically found in alkaline urine and are associated with struvite stones.

 

Urinary Crystals and pH Association:

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came with complaints of orange hue over the body with hyperkeratotic perifollicular erythematous papules associated with scaling, which started near the face and slowly progressed to involve the entire body. Islands of sparing noted over the body. Palmoplantar keratoderma noted. Histology shows alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) is a rare skin disorder characterized by orange-red plaques, hyperkeratotic follicular papules, and scaling that typically starts on the face and progresses caudally (cephalocaudal spread) to involve the entire body.

 

A hallmark feature is the presence of “islands of sparing,” where patches of normal skin are surrounded by erythematous areas. The thickening of the skin over the palms and soles, known as palmoplantar keratoderma, is another distinguishing feature of PRP.

Histologically, PRP shows a distinctive pattern known as the "checkerboard" pattern, characterized by alternating areas of orthokeratosis (normal keratinization) and parakeratosis (abnormal keratinization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that typically presents as patchy erythematous lesions, often resembling eczema or psoriasis, but it does not exhibit the cephalocaudal spread or islands of sparing characteristic of PRP. The histological findings also differ, with atypical lymphocytes being a hallmark of mycosis fungoides rather than the checkerboard pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option B. Follicular psoriasis: Psoriasis, including its follicular variant, usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered by silvery scales. While it may involve the palms and soles, the orange hue, islands of sparing, and cephalocaudal spread are not typical of psoriasis. Histologically, psoriasis shows uniform parakeratosis and elongation of the rete ridges rather than the alternating pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis: Also known as Darier's disease, keratosis follicularis presents with greasy, warty papules, often in seborrheic areas. It lacks the distinctive orange hue, islands of sparing, and palmoplantar keratoderma seen in PRP. Histologically, Darier’s disease shows suprabasal acantholysis and dyskeratosis rather than the orthokeratosis and parakeratosis found in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by an orange-red hue with cephalocaudal spread, islands of sparing, palmoplantar keratoderma, and a histological "checkerboard" pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.text: Keratoderma Blennorrhagicum is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Reactive Arthritis

 

Explanation: 

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a characteristic skin manifestation of Reactive Arthritis. Reactive Arthritis (formerly known as Reiter's syndrome) typically presents with a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, often following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections. Keratoderma blennorrhagicum appears as pustular skin lesions that resemble psoriasis, typically on the palms and soles. It is considered part of the characteristic clinical presentation of reactive arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis - RA is characterized by symmetric polyarthritis, morning stiffness, and systemic manifestations. Skin manifestations in RA include rheumatoid nodules, but not keratoderma blennorrhagicum, which is specific to reactive arthritis.

 

Option B. Psoriatic Arthritis - While psoriatic arthritis does have skin manifestations (primarily psoriatic plaques), keratoderma blennorrhagicum specifically refers to the pustular lesions seen in reactive arthritis. Though they can appear similar to pustular psoriasis, they are distinct clinical entities.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis - AS primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing sacroiliitis and spinal fusion. While it shares genetic associations (HLA-B27) with reactive arthritis, keratoderma blennorrhagicum is not a typical manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum, characterized by pustular skin lesions resembling psoriasis on the palms and soles, is a distinctive cutaneous manifestation of Reactive Arthritis, which typically occurs following gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely disease looking at the pattern of inheritance as provided in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

The pedigree in the image shows an inheritance pattern typical of X-linked recessive conditions. In this pattern, affected males inherit the disease from carrier mothers, while females are usually carriers and do not show the disease. All affected individuals are male, and carrier females are represented by circles with a dot. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilson’s disease: This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both males and females are equally affected, and carriers are not seen in the pattern observed here.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It would appear in every generation and affect both males and females equally, which is not the case in the presented pedigree.

 

Option D. Leber disease: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is inherited through maternal (mitochondrial) inheritance. It does not follow an X-linked recessive pattern and affects both sexes through maternal transmission only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked recessive conditions are characterized by affected males and carrier females, as males have only one X chromosome, making them susceptible if the gene is defective.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE")

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?  NEET PG 2019
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Candidal intertrigo

 

The condition shown in the image is Candidal intertrigo.

 

Various types of candidiasis:

 

  1. Candidal intertrigo:
    • Manifests with erythematous, non-scaly moist patches of opposing skin surfaces, with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold.
    • When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.
    • Tiny, superficial, white pustular satellite lesions can be seen at the margins of the intertriginous patch.
  2. Candidal paronychia: Swelling of nail fold
  3. Candidal balanoposthitis: Seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, associated with swelling of prepuce.
  4. Perlèche/ Angular stomatitis: Soreness and cracking at the angles of the mouth are seen in Perlèche. It is considered as an intertrigo where candida is the most common organism implicated.

 

 

Investigations:

 

  • KOH mount → Pseudo hyphae

 

Treatment:

 

  • Topical: Antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.
  • Oral: Fluconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal paronychia

  • This refers to an infection of the nail fold, leading to a painful and red swelling around the nail.
  • It can be due to bacterial or candidal infection.

 

Option C. Diabetic foot ulcer

  • This is an open sore or wound commonly located on the bottom of the foot in people with diabetes.
  • Factors leading to diabetic foot ulcers include neuropathy, peripheral arterial disease, foot deformities, and trauma.
  • The skin around the ulcer may be calloused or discolored but not typically macerated.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

  • This is a serious skin disorder caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It primarily affects infants and young children.
  • It is characterized by blistering and the appearance that the top layer of skin is scalded or burned.
  • SSSS affects larger areas of the body and often starts with facial erythema, widespread redness, and blisters, which then rupture, leaving raw areas. Maceration of toe web spaces would not be a primary symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candidal intertrigo can be identified by the classic presentation of erythema, maceration, and possible white exudate in skin folds, such as the web spaces between fingers, distinguishing it from conditions that affect the nail folds, feet, or involve widespread skin desquamation.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 32, Page nos 32.61-32.63

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

It is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to gradually deteriorate, eventually leading to thyroid failure. It is most common in women between the ages of 45 and 65. The presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase causes it.

 

There is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with an intact capsule morphologically. It is clearly separated from the surrounding structures.

 

There are two types of Hashimoto's thyroiditis: the classic form, which is more common, and the fibrosing variant, which occurs in only 10% of cases.

 

The classic form is distinguished by diffuse, symmetric, firm, and rubbery thyroid enlargement. The fibrosing variant has a firm, enlarged thyroid with surrounding tissue compression.

 

Histologically:

 

  1. Classic form has intense lymphocytic infiltration, atrophied thyroid follicles, and follicular epithelial cells that have degenerated into Hurthle cells (also called Askanazy cells, or oxyphil cells, or oncocytes).
  2. The fibrosing variant of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by significant fibrous replacement of thyroid parenchyma and a less prominent lymphoid infiltrate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graves' disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, presence of anti-TSH receptor antibodies, and typically does not present with Hurthle cells.

 

  • Clinical features include exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and a diffusely enlarged hypervascular thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma: A type of thyroid cancer that presents with different histological features, such as follicular cell proliferation and capsular or vascular invasion, but not typically Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with amyloid deposits and elevated calcitonin levels.

 

  • Histologically different from Hashimoto's thyroiditis and does not feature Hurthle cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitting of nails

 

The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

Alopecia areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.28-33

questions.text: JAK2 mutation is most commonly associated with? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycythemia vera

 

Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

The exact etiology of PV is not known but about a third of cases show inconsistent and varied chromosomal abnormalities such as 20q, trisomy 8 and 9p. Major pathogenetic mechanism is a tyrosine kinase JAK2 mutation which removes the autoinhibitory control and activates the kinases.

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is an acquired, somatic mutation present in the majority of patients with myeloproliferative cancer (myeloproliferative neoplasms) i.e. nearly 100% of patients with polycythemia vera and in about 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis and primary myelofibrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Essential thrombocytosis: The JAK2 V617F mutation is also found in approximately 50% of patients with essential thrombocytosis, but it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Option C. CML (Chronic Myeloid Leukemia): CML is associated with the Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22) translocation), not the JAK2 mutation.

 

Option D. PMF (Primary Myelofibrosis): The JAK2 mutation is present in about 50% of patients with PMF, but again, it is most strongly associated with polycythemia vera.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The JAK2 V617F mutation is most commonly associated with polycythemia vera, where it drives the excessive production of red blood cells through constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1161

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

 

The absence of CD40 and its deficiency in B cells results in Hyper IgM syndrome. This condition is characterized by a reduction in IgG levels and an elevation in IgM levels.

 

HYPER IGM SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lack of natural killer cells: This is not associated with CD40 deficiency but rather with other immune disorders like severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

 

Option B. Lack of CD8 mediated cytotoxicity: CD40/CD40L interactions do not directly affect CD8 T cells. CD8 mediated cytotoxicity is more related to T cell receptor function and MHC class I interactions.

 

Option D. Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections: While CD40 deficiency can lead to an increased susceptibility to infections, neutrophil function is not directly impaired by the absence of CD40. This function is more related to chronic granulomatous disease or other neutrophil defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyper IgM syndrome is characterized by an increased level of IgM and decreased levels of other immunoglobulins like IgG, due to a defect in the CD40/CD40L interaction necessary for immunoglobulin class switching.

questions.text: Which of the following leukotrienes is not a vasoconstrictor? ( NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Leukotriene B4

 

Explanation: 

 

Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) is primarily a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils, causing aggregation and adhesion of neutrophils to venular endothelium. Unlike the other leukotrienes listed (C4, D4, and E4), LTB4 does not function as a vasoconstrictor in the inflammatory response. Instead, it primarily mediates leukocyte recruitment and activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leukotriene C4 - This is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that causes intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, and increased permeability of venules. It is part of the slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis (SRS-A).

 

Option B. Leukotriene D4 - Similar to LTC4, it is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that functions as a vasoconstrictor and bronchospasm inducer. It is also part of SRS-A and contributes to increased vascular permeability.

 

Option C. Leukotriene E4 - This is also a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene with vasoconstriction properties similar to LTC4 and LTD4. It is part of SRS-A and contributes to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leukotriene B4 differs from LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 in that it primarily functions as a chemotactic agent for leukocytes rather than causing vasoconstriction, making it a key mediator in leukocyte recruitment during inflammation.

questions.text: Match the following cancers with their respective genes involved: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

1. KIT (D): Commonly mutated in Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs), where it plays a critical role in tumor growth and survival.

 

2. K-RAS (C): Frequently mutated in pancreatic cancers, contributing to the cancerous cells’ growth and division.

 

3. JAK 2 (A): Mutations in JAK 2 are associated with various types of myeloproliferative neoplasms, affecting blood cell production.

 

4. ALK (B): ALK gene rearrangements are a key driver in a subset of non-small cell lung cancers, particularly adenocarcinoma, leading to targeted treatment approaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenocarcinoma lung: Associated with mutations or rearrangements in ALK, making ALK inhibitors a treatment option.
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm: JAK 2 mutations enhance the understanding and treatment of these diseases.
  • Pancreatic Carcinoma: Known for K-RAS mutations which are pivotal in the development and progression of pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: An adult patient presents with tall stature, pigeon chest deformity, long arm span, lens dislocation, and cardiac defects. This patient is likely to have a defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibrillin

 

The clinical presentation described is strongly suggests Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting connective tissue.

 

Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene, which encodes fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the formation of elastic fibers in connective tissue. Features of Marfan syndrome include tall stature, long arms, pigeon chest (pectus carinatum), lens dislocation (typically upward and temporal), and cardiac defects such as aortic aneurysm and mitral valve prolapse. The defect in fibrillin leads to the characteristic physical and systemic manifestations of the syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elastase: Elastase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of elastin and is associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, leading to conditions like emphysema. It is not related to Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. Collagen: Collagen defects are associated with other connective tissue disorders, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Alport syndrome. Collagen abnormalities do not explain the specific features of Marfan syndrome.

 

Option D. Laminin: Laminin is a major glycoprotein in the extracellular matrix, playing a key role in cell adhesion and structural integrity of tissues. It is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan syndrome is characterized by a defect in fibrillin-1 due to mutations in the FBN1 gene, leading to tall stature, skeletal deformities, lens dislocation, and cardiovascular abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following inclusion bodies are seen in Alzheimer's Disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hirano bodies

 

Explanation: 

 

Hirano bodies are eosinophilic rod-shaped intraneuronal inclusion bodies found in Alzheimer's disease. They represent actin aggregates found within neurons, particularly in the hippocampus. These inclusions are one of the characteristic microscopic findings in Alzheimer's disease, along with the more prominent neurofibrillary tangles (composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein) and amyloid plaques (composed of Aβ peptide). Hirano bodies are not specific to Alzheimer's disease but are commonly observed in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bunina bodies - These are small eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in motor neurons in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). They are not characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Option B. Lewy bodies - These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic neuronal inclusions composed of α-synuclein. They are the hallmark of Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia, not Alzheimer's disease. They appear as round eosinophilic inclusions in the substantia nigra and other regions.

 

Option D. Lafora bodies - These are intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of polyglucosan found in Lafora body disease, a rare form of progressive myoclonic epilepsy. They are not associated with Alzheimer's disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Hirano bodies are actin-containing eosinophilic rod-shaped inclusions found in neurons in Alzheimer's disease, particularly in the hippocampus, representing one of several characteristic microscopic findings alongside the more diagnostically significant neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Divalent metal transporter 1

 

DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.

 

Luminal nonheme iron is mostly in the Fe [3] + (ferric state and is reduced to Fe [2] + (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases, such as b cytochromes and STEAP3. Fe [2] + iron is then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

Fe [2] + iron destined for the circulation, is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin. This process is coupled to the oxidation of Fe [2] + iron to Fe [3] + iron, which is carried out by the iron oxidases hephaestin and ceruloplasmin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferroportin: Ferroportin is not involved in the initial transport of iron into the enterocyte. Instead, it is responsible for exporting iron from the enterocyte into the bloodstream. Ferroportin also works in tandem with hephaestin to ensure that Fe²⁺ iron is oxidized to Fe³⁺ before being released into circulation.

 

Option C. Divalent metal transporter 2: There is no known transporter named "Divalent metal transporter 2" involved in iron absorption or transport within enterocytes. This option is incorrect and may be a distractor or incorrect reference.

 

Option D. Haptocorrin: Haptocorrin is a protein that binds vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in the stomach, protecting it from degradation. It is not involved in iron transport or metabolism, making this option incorrect in the context of iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is critical for the transport of Fe²⁺ iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes, facilitating iron absorption in the gut.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1230

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following nutrients can lead to delayed wound healing? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including DNA synthesis, cell division, and protein synthesis, all of which are vital for wound healing. Zinc is a cofactor for numerous enzymes, including matrix metalloproteinases, which are involved in the remodeling of extracellular matrix during wound healing. A deficiency in zinc impairs these processes, leading to delayed wound healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron: Iron is important for oxygen transport and cellular respiration, but its deficiency primarily leads to anemia and fatigue rather than directly causing delayed wound healing.

 

Option B. Magnesium: Magnesium is involved in many biochemical reactions, but its deficiency is more likely to cause muscle cramps, arrhythmias, and neuromuscular issues rather than significantly impacting wound healing.

 

Option D. Manganese: Manganese is a trace mineral important for bone formation and metabolism. While it is involved in enzyme function, its deficiency is less commonly linked to delayed wound healing compared to zinc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc is required for functioning of matrix metalloproteases and so, required for proper wound healing. Any deficiency of zinc can lead to delayed wound healing.

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exposure to cold temperature

 

  • Cutis marmorata, also known as physiological livedo reticularis, describes the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of the skin that occurs when exposed to cold temperatures.

 

Fig: Cutis marmorata

 

  • During infancy, about half of all children exhibit a noticeable marbling pattern on their skin when exposed to cooler temperatures.
  • This effect arises from the simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries and may continue throughout early childhood.
  • However, the skin returns to its regular appearance when warmed again, indicating that this is a natural physiological response and does not necessitate any intervention.
  • Nevertheless, persistent cutis marmorata may be observed in individuals with trisomies 18 and 21.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exposure to hot temperature

 

 

Erythema Ab Igne over thigh

 

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs: They can cause various skin manifestations, including rashes, urticaria, or specific reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not cutis marmorata.

 

Option D. Humidity: It is not known to cause cutis marmorata. High humidity can lead to other skin issues like sweating and chafing, but it does not cause the vascular changes seen in cutis marmorata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutis marmorata is a skin condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the skin, resulting from exposure to cold temperatures due to the vascular response of constriction and dilation.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 25, Page no 125.7

 

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7447 Unique Key-Q6575185

questions.text: Which region of the liver is most vulnerable to ischemic injury? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Centrilobular

 

Explanation: 

 

The centrilobular region (Zone 3) is most vulnerable to ischemic injury because it is located farthest from the blood supply. Blood flows from portal tracts (containing branches of portal vein and hepatic artery) toward the central vein, creating an oxygen gradient. Hepatocytes in the centrilobular region receive blood that has already passed through other zones, making them most susceptible to hypoxia during compromised circulation. Left-sided cardiac failure or shock may lead to hepatic hypoperfusion and hypoxia, causing ischemic coagulative necrosis of hepatocytes in the central region of the lobule (centrilobular necrosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periportal - The periportal region (Zone 1) is closest to the incoming blood supply from both portal vein and hepatic artery branches. It receives blood with the highest oxygen concentration, making it most resistant to ischemic injury.

 

Option B. Midzonal - The midzonal region (Zone 2) lies between periportal and centrilobular areas. It has intermediate vulnerability to ischemic injury, becoming affected after the centrilobular region but before the periportal region.

 

Option D. Perihepatic - This is not a standard term in liver lobular architecture. The liver lobule is divided into centrilobular, midzonal, and periportal regions based on proximity to central veins and portal tracts.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The centrilobular region is most vulnerable to ischemic injury due to its location farthest from the blood supply, making it the first area to suffer during hypoxic conditions like cardiac failure or shock.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with itchy lesions on the wrist and involvement of oral mucosa, and on examination, following findings were noted. What will be the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lichen Planus

 

The skin lesion in the preceding image features the distinctive purple, flat, polygonal papules of lichen planus.

 

Lichen planus:

 

  • The five characteristics of lichen planus lesions are 5Ps: purple polygonal, pruritic, plane topped (flat), and papules.
  • Lichen planus has characteristics including cicatrizing alopecia, flat-topped purple polygonal papules, and plaques on the flexural aspect of the wrist, Wickham's striae on the lips, longitudinal ridging, and thinning of nails.
  • Lichen planus producing Cicatrizing/Scarring alopecia

 

  • In almost 30–70% of cases with lichen planus, mucous membrane lesions develop. It primarily affects the anal and genital mucosa as well as the tongue and buccal mucosa.
  • Wickham's striae are distinctive white streaks that create a lacework in the buccal mucosa.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lichen nitidus

 

  • Features: Lichen nitidus presents as tiny, flesh-coloured, shiny papules, primarily on the abdomen, chest, forearms, and genitals. It doesn't usually involve the oral mucosa.
  • Why it doesn't match: The primary presentation doesn't involve oral mucosa, and the typical presentation is different from the described symptoms.

 

Option C. Psoriasis

 

  • Features: Psoriasis often presents with sharply demarcated, erythematous, scaly plaques. Common locations include the knees, elbows, and scalp. Nail changes (like pitting) can be observed. The oral mucosa is rarely involved.
  • Why it doesn't match: While psoriasis can affect various parts of the body, involvement of the oral mucosa is uncommon. The described presentation fits lichen planus better.

 

Option D. Chicken pox

 

  • Features: Chicken pox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus and presents as an itchy rash that evolves into fluid-filled vesicles. The lesions progress to pustules and then crust over. It starts on the face and trunk and spreads outward. Oral lesions can be present but are usually ulcers.
  • Why it doesn't match: The progression and appearance of chicken pox lesions differ from the described presentation. Also, chicken pox usually has a systemic presentation with fever and malaise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen planus is recognized as the characteristic pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques, often with Wickham's striae, and the presence of lacy white lesions on the oral mucosa.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 31.24, 34.39, 35.1, 37.1, 37.4, 37.6

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lack of differentiation

 

A lack of differentiation is referred to as anaplasia.

 

Anaplasia means "backward formation," implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level.

 

As a result of anaplasia, morphological and functional changes in the neoplastic cells are observed like:

 

  • Loss of polarity
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:5 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Nucleolar changes - prominent nucleolus or nucleoli in the nucleus reflecting increased nucleoprotein synthesis
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Tumour giant cells
  • Functional (Cytoplasmic) changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variation in cell size and shape: This is a feature of pleomorphism, a characteristic of anaplasia but not the definition of it.

 

Option C. Replacement of one type of cell by another: This describes metaplasia.

 

Option D. Disordered arrangement of tumor cells: This can be a feature seen in anaplastic tumors but is not definitive for anaplasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasia indicates a high grade of malignancy due to the significant loss of differentiation and structural and functional changes in the neoplastic cells.

questions.text: The deletion of a single alpha globin gene on one chromosome is best described as: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Alpha Thalassemia silent carrier.

 

Explanation: 

 

The deletion of a single alpha globin gene on one chromosome (represented as α/α -/-) is classified as alpha thalassemia silent carrier state. Normally, there are four alpha globin genes in total (two on each chromosome 16). The silent carrier state results from the deletion of just one alpha globin gene, causing a barely detectable reduction in alpha-globin chain synthesis.
