Individuals with this condition are completely asymptomatic but might have slight microcytosis (small red cells). This represents the mildest form of alpha thalassemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hb Barts - This is incorrect. Hemoglobin Barts is a tetrameric gamma globin chain (γ4) that forms when there is severe alpha chain deficiency. It is associated with the complete absence of alpha globin genes (hydrops fetalis) or the deletion of three alpha globin genes (HbH disease), not with the loss of a single gene.

 

Option B. Alpha thalassemia major - This is incorrect. Alpha thalassemia major (hydrops fetalis) results from the deletion of all four alpha globin genes (--/--), causing severe intrauterine anemia and typically resulting in death in utero or shortly after birth without intervention.

 

Option C. Alpha thalassemia trait - This is incorrect. Alpha thalassemia trait results from the deletion of two alpha globin genes, either both from the same chromosome (--/αα) or one from each chromosome (-α/-α). This causes mild microcytic anemia without significant clinical symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha thalassemia silent carrier state is caused by the deletion of a single alpha globin gene, resulting in minimal hematological changes without clinical symptoms, representing the mildest form in the spectrum of alpha thalassemia disorders.

questions.text: A patient had a history of thorn prick while working in a rose garden and later observed linear spread proximally till his shoulder. What is the underlying cause for this clinical feature? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphangitis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is lymphangitis. The patient presents with a history of a thorn prick followed by a linear spread of lesions, which is indicative of sporotrichosis.

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," is caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. The infection typically occurs when the fungus is inoculated into the skin through a thorn prick. The characteristic clinical feature is a linear pattern of nodulo-ulcerative lesions that follow the lymphatic vessels, resulting in lymphangitis.

 

 

Asteroid bodies in sporotrichosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blaschkitis: This condition follows Blaschko's lines and is unrelated to thorn pricks or fungal infections.

 

Option C. Abscess: An abscess is a localized collection of pus within tissues, usually caused by bacterial infection, and does not typically present with a linear pattern of spread.

 

Option D. Furuncle: A furuncle, or boil, is a painful infection of a hair follicle and surrounding tissue caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It does not present with a linear pattern of lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It presents with a linear pattern of nodulo-ulcerative lesions following the lymphatic vessels, leading to lymphangitis. This is typically seen after a thorn prick or similar injury.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

Follicular lymphoma is associated with overexpression of BCL2.

 

Normal cells include the BCL2 gene, however this gene's mutant version with the recognizable translocation t (14;18) (q32; q21) was originally identified in B-cell lymphoma, hence the term BCL.

 

Numerous other human malignancies, including those of the breast, thyroid, and prostate, also exhibit it.

 

Due to a mutation in the BCL2 gene, more living cells are undergoing mitosis, which contributes to the formation of tumors by removing the apoptosis-inhibitory control on cancer cells.

 

The most prevalent chromosomal translocation in human lymphomas, the t(14;18)  (q32;q21) is found in up to 30% of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas and over 85% of follicular lymphomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt lymphoma: Characterized by the c-MYC gene translocation, not BCL2 overexpression.

 

Option C. Diffuse large-cell lymphoma: While BCL2 can be overexpressed due to the same translocation, it is more typically associated with follicular lymphoma.

 

Option D. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL): CLL can also exhibit overexpression of BCL2, but this is generally due to other genetic mechanisms rather than the t(14;18) translocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is primarily associated with the overexpression of BCL2 due to the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation. This genetic alteration is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma, enabling lymphoma cells to evade apoptosis and sustain tumor growth. Understanding the role of BCL2 in various lymphomas helps in differentiating among them and tailoring appropriate therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: Alder-Reilly bodies are found in: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Mucopolysaccharidosis.

 

Explanation: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are azurophilic, metachromatic granules found in leukocytes (neutrophils, eosinophils, basophils, monocytes, and lymphocytes) in patients with mucopolysaccharidosis. These abnormal inclusions represent accumulations of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans) within the cytoplasm of these cells. Mucopolysaccharidoses are a group of inherited lysosomal storage disorders characterized by defective degradation of glycosaminoglycans due to enzyme deficiencies, leading to their accumulation in various tissues including blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Large platelets - This is incorrect. Large platelets are associated with several conditions including Bernard-Soulier syndrome, May-Hegglin anomaly, and immune thrombocytopenic purpura, but these do not feature Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option C. Alport's syndrome - This is incorrect. Alport's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities. It's caused by mutations in genes coding for type IV collagen and does not involve the formation of Alder-Reilly bodies.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi syndrome - This is incorrect. While Chediak-Higashi syndrome does involve abnormal granules in leukocytes, these are giant lysosomal granules rather than Alder-Reilly bodies. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and giant granules in leukocytes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alder-Reilly bodies are distinctive azurophilic granular inclusions found in leukocytes of patients with mucopolysaccharidosis, representing accumulated glycosaminoglycans due to defective lysosomal enzyme function.

choices.text: Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli
Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

questions.text: Which is the most important light microscopic feature of irreversible cell injury? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nuclear changes like pyknosis and karyolysis

 

The most important light microscopic features of irreversible cell injury are nuclear changes. These changes are indicative of cell death and include:

 

  • Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes dense, with chromatin condensing into a solid, darkly staining mass.
  • Karyorrhexis: The pyknotic nucleus fragments into smaller pieces.
  • Karyolysis: The nuclear fragments dissolve and fade, leading to the eventual loss of the nucleus.

 

These nuclear changes are hallmark signs of irreversible cell damage and cell death, distinguishing them from reversible changes such as cellular swelling or detachment of ribosomes from the endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amorphous densities in mitochondria: These changes are often seen in irreversible cell injury, particularly in the context of mitochondrial dysfunction, but nuclear changes are more definitive indicators of irreversible damage.

 

Option B. Cell membrane blebs and loss of microvilli: These features are associated with reversible cell injury, not irreversible injury. They indicate cellular swelling and loss of structural integrity but do not signify cell death.

 

Option C. Ribosomal detachment from endoplasmic reticulum: This is also a feature of reversible cell injury, indicating disruption in protein synthesis, but it does not define irreversible injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyknosis, karyorrhexis, and karyolysis on light microscopy are signs of irreversible cell injury.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

questions.text: A 25 year old woman discovers a well-defined, mobile and rubbery breast lump measuring 2.5 x 6 cm on self-examination. The lesion is painless and has been stable over several months. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the described characteristics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The given scenario describes a young female with a well-defined, mobile lump in the breast, which is characteristic of a breast mouse or fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that typically present as freely mobile masses in young women. They consist of an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma. Depending on the arrangement of the fibrous tissue, fibroadenomas can be classified as pericanalicular or intracanalicular subtypes. Notably, the use of the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporine has been associated with an increased risk of developing fibroadenomas.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DCIS (Ductal Carcinoma In Situ), Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma, and Option D. Intraductal papilloma are all malignant or precancerous lesions that would typically present with additional signs such as skin dimpling, nipple retraction, or ulceration, rather than as a mobile, painless lump in a young woman.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are the most common cause of benign, mobile breast lumps in young women. They are characterized by an overgrowth of fibrous tissue in the breast stroma and may be associated with the use of cyclosporine.

questions.text: The given condition is caused by which drug? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bleomycin

 

  • The given image shows flagellate dermatitis. It is caused by bleomycin.
  • Flagellate dermatoses are infrequent types of figurate dermatoses characterized by parallel lines or curves resembling whiplash marks.
  • Bleomycin, a polypeptide chemotherapeutic agent, primarily affects the respiratory and cutaneous systems, likely due to the absence of the inactivating enzyme hydrolase in these tissues.

 

 

  • It manifests as widespread, itchy, flagellate, erythematous plaques on the trunk and extremities within hours to months after bleomycin administration.
  • Flagellate hyperpigmentation may persist even after the rash has resolved.
  • While there is no specific treatment for this condition, avoiding bleomycin can lead to clearance of the symptoms over several months to years.
  • However, re-exposure to the drug might trigger a more severe reaction.
  • Bleomycin is also associated with development of pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Peplomycin, a bleomycin derivative with reduced pulmonary toxicity, is utilized in the treatment of prostatic carcinoma and lymphomas. Nevertheless, it has been associated with flagellate erythema through mechanisms like those of bleomycin.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Bleomycin, on the other hand, can cause skin side effects like flagellate erythema, which appears as streaky red or hyperpigmented lines on the skin, resembling the appearance in the image provided. This particular side effect is a hallmark of Bleomycin toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students and residents, it is crucial to identify bleomycin as the chemotherapeutic agent that can cause flagellate hyperpigmentation, a dermatological side effect not commonly associated with actinomycin, mitomycin C, or doxorubicin.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 4 & 120, Page no 4.12 & 120.8

Goodman & Gillman’s The pharmacological basis of therapeutics 13th edition Page no 1193

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3702947/

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/share/F7KSRDKWUJX3W2GZTEAC?target=10.1002/ski2.92

questions.text: Varicella-zoster virus remains dormant in the: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Dorsal root ganglion

 

  • Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear.
  • The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised
  • The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral root

  • It is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • The ventral root carries motor neurons, not sensory neurons, and VZV is not known to remain dormant in motor neurons or their associated structures.

 

Option B. Skin

  • It is not a site of viral latency.
  • While VZV does cause lesions in the skin, it does not remain dormant there.
  • Skin lesions occur during active infection when the virus reactivates and travels down sensory nerves to the skin.

 

Option C. Medulla oblongata

  • It is a part of the brainstem and is not associated with the latency of VZV.
  • This virus specifically becomes dormant in the peripheral nervous system, not within the central nervous system structures such as the medulla oblongata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal root ganglion is the site of latency for the Varicella-zoster virus, which is important for understanding the pathogenesis of both primary varicella infection and reactivation as herpes zoster.

 

Reference

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

Question Level – EASY

Question Id-7448 Unique Key-Q4313194

questions.text: What is the most common anemia in a 65-year-old female? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia globally, including in a 65-year-old female. While it is true that menstruation is a common cause of iron deficiency anemia in younger women, older women can still be susceptible due to other factors.

 

In elderly patients, particularly in females, iron deficiency anemia can arise from a variety of causes, including:

 

  • Nutritional deficiencies: This remains a leading cause, especially in developing countries where dietary iron intake may be insufficient.
  • Gastrointestinal blood loss: This is a significant concern in elderly patients. Conditions such as peptic ulcers, hemorrhoids, and gastrointestinal malignancies (like colon cancer) are common causes of chronic blood loss, leading to iron deficiency anemia.
  • Malabsorption syndromes: Conditions that impair the absorption of iron from the gastrointestinal tract can also contribute to iron deficiency anemia.

 

The confusion might arise from the assumption that post-menopausal women are less likely to suffer from iron deficiency anemia due to the cessation of menstrual bleeding. However, it is important to recognize that other causes, especially chronic blood loss from the gastrointestinal tract, become more prevalent with age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia of chronic disease: This type of anemia is common in the elderly, particularly those with chronic illnesses like rheumatoid arthritis or chronic infections. However, iron deficiency anemia remains the most common overall.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic anemia: This anemia is usually due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. While it is more common in the elderly, it is not as prevalent as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Pernicious anemia: A specific type of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency due to intrinsic factor deficiency. While it can be common in older adults, it is not the most common cause of anemia overall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common type of anemia in a 65-year-old female, with causes shifting from menstrual blood loss in younger women to chronic gastrointestinal blood loss (due to malignancies) and nutritional deficiencies in the elderly.

questions.text: The possible diagnosis for a child whose mother had a history of bronchial asthma & child developed itchy plaques bilaterally over the popliteal fossa, & cubital fossa (as shown below) could be? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays a child, with scratch marks and excoriations from itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, with a maternal history of bronchial asthma indicative of

 

Atopic dermatitis (or eczema).

 

  • This chronic inflammatory skin condition often occurs in families with atopy, encompassing asthma, hay fever, and allergic rhinitis.
  • The patient's personal history reveals a chronic and recurrent course of this condition.

 

In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.

 

  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  • Infantile
  • Childhood
  • Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas.
  • Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following 
    • Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any topic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • It is frequently observed in individuals in their 40s.
  • This is an intensely pruritic condition predominantly affecting extensor surfaces of the body, rather than the flexures and associated with gluten sensitivity and is characterized by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. It is not related to a history of atopy.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vegetans:

 

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus vegetans presents with vegetating plaques, usually in the intertriginous areas.
  • It is not associated with a familial history of atopy and does not predominantly affect the popliteal and cubital fossae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques.
  • While psoriasis can affect any area of the body but more commonly extensor involvement is seen, it does not typically present as pruritic plaques in the popliteal

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with a familial history of atopy presenting with itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, Atopic Dermatitis is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19, volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Atopic_dermatitis

questions.text: The patient visiting the outpatient department exhibits skin manifestations linked to a disease that includes Raynaud’s phenomenon. What is this skin manifestation shown below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and pepper pigmentation.

 

  • The presented clinical scenario indicates systemic sclerosis, a complex autoimmune condition of uncertain origin with diverse clinical manifestations.
  • It leads to considerable disability and mortality, affecting nearly all organs.
  • The defining feature of systemic sclerosis is scleroderma, characterized by thickened and indurated skin.

 

Systemic sclerosis

 

It also presents with typical skin manifestations of Raynaud phenomenon, which include the characteristic white discoloration of the fingers due to vasospasm and bluish discoloration of the fingertips as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.

 

 

  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Puffy fingers in early disease
  • Severe flexion contractures
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose can be seen as shown in the image below

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and Dermatomyositis.

 

Option C: Sometimes the color of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as leukotrichia.

 

Option D: Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and Pepper pigmentation' is a cutaneous manifestation often seen in systemic sclerosis, a condition which also commonly presents with Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 56 page no 56.4

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 2779

questions.text: A person undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

 

BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID

 

  • Immunobullous disease with a sub epidermal split
  • IgG is the autoantibody deposited
  • Target protein: Hemi desmosomes
  • Target antigens: BPAG 2 > 1
  • No acantholysis
    • Clinical Features: Involves primary lesions (Tense pruritic bullae on Erythematous skin or normal skin) and secondary lesions (Itchy Bullae → Erosions due to scratching).
    • Sites: Trunk, abdomen, flexural aspects of extremities, 10-30% of patients have oral erosions.

 

 

  • Investigation:

 

1. Tzanck smear: Presence of eosinophils and Absence of acantholytic cells.

 

2. Histopathology:

 

 

3. Direct Immunofluorescence: show IgG, C3 linear deposits along Basement Membrane Zone.

 

 

  • Treatment: Topical steroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vulgaris: Involves intraepidermal blisters and suprabasal acantholysis (separation of skin cells), which are not described in the provided scenario. Direct Immunofluorescence would typically show intercellular deposits, not linear along the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Characterized by intensely itchy blisters and associated with gluten sensitivity. Direct Immunofluorescence shows granular IgA deposits at the tips of dermal papillae, not the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous: Presents with superficial (epidermal) blisters that do not affect the deeper layers of the skin. The immunofluorescence pattern would not show the linear deposition along the basement membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullous Pemphigoid in patients undergoing immunotherapy is critical due to the potential severity of the condition and the need for prompt and effective management to reduce symptoms and prevent complications. Monitoring for new or worsening symptoms in patients on immunotherapy is essential to catch such reactions early.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of her hand is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an easily visible and early sign of vitamin B12 deficiency due to increase in tyrosinase activity. It may occur even before the development of hematological and neurological complications.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: This condition involves pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow but does not typically present with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency anemia: Iron deficiency anemia usually presents with pallor and fatigue but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation.

 

Option D. Hypoalbuminemia: Hypoalbuminemia may cause edema and other systemic symptoms but is not associated with knuckle pigmentation or anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Knuckle pigmentation is an early and visible sign of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can precede the more severe hematological and neurological complications associated with megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.

 

Key Characteristics of Borderline Leprosy

 

  • Lesions: Borderline leprosy often presents with numerous skin lesions which may be macular (flat), papular (raised), or annular (ring-shaped) with less defined borders compared to tuberculoid leprosy. The lesions can sometimes exhibit an "inverted saucer" appearance, where the center appears slightly depressed.
  • Symmetry: The lesions tend to be asymmetrical.
  • Sensory Loss: These lesions usually show some sensory loss, although not as pronounced as in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Reactivity: Borderline leprosy is particularly unstable immunologically, prone to reactivations and shifts toward either more or less severe forms, depending on immune changes in the individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy: Closer to the tuberculoid pole with fewer, well-defined lesions and significant nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy: At the opposite pole from tuberculoid leprosy, characterized by numerous lesions including nodules and plaques, with a high bacterial load but minimal sensory loss.

 

Option D. Histoid Leprosy: A rare variant of lepromatous leprosy presenting as nodules and plaques, often occurring in patients who have experienced leprosy treatment or relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

questions.text: Fever occurs during inflammation due to all except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Histamine 

 

Histamine is involved in the mediation of inflammatory vascular events rather than fever.

 

Fever is defined by an increase in body temperature of 1° to 4°C. It is a prominent manifestation of the acute-phase response, particularly when associated with infection.

 

Pyrogens are substances that cause fever. They can be either exogenous or endogenous.

 

  • Endogenous progens include IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
  • Exogenous pyrogens are bacterial lipopolysaccharides that stimulate leukocytes to release endogenous progens (IL-1 and TNF)

 

Cytokines increase the activity of cyclooxygenases, which convert arachidonic acid into prostaglandins. These prostaglandins are produced in the hypothalamic vascular and perivascular cells. They stimulate the production of neurotransmitters in the hypothalamus, which raises the temperature setpoint. This is especially true of PGE2.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. IL-1, B. Prostaglandins and C. TNF: These are all endogenous pyrogens that directly contribute to the fever response by influencing the temperature regulation in the hypothalamus and stimulating the production of prostaglandins that raise the body’s temperature setpoint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histamine is involved in mediating the local vascular effects of inflammation and not in the fever response, which is primarily driven by IL-1, TNF, and prostaglandins.
